required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparing the Shape and Frequency of Uterine Contractions

brief_summary.textblock: Dystocia is the most common indication for primary cesarean section. The most common cause of dystocia is uterine dysfunction. In all cephalopelvic disproportion studies, more attention is usually paid on fetus and pelvic rather than on the role of uterine contraction in delivery. So we decided to determine the relationship between dystocia and uterine contraction patterns.

primary_outcome.measure: the shape and frequency of uterine contractions
primary_outcome.description: Uterus contractions were recorded using electronic fetal monitoring at the beginning of the active phase of labor (dilatation 3-5 cm) for 30 min.

arm_group.arm_group_label: the shape and frequency of uterine contractions in delivery
arm_group.description: Uterine contractions were recorded by using fetal monitoring system (Model FC1400) at the beginning of the active phase (cervical dilatation 3-4 cm) for 30 min in two groups.

arm_group.arm_group_label: the shape and frequency of uterine contractions in cesarean
arm_group.description: Uterine contractions were recorded by using fetal monitoring system (Model FC1400) at the beginning of the active phase (cervical dilatation 3-4 cm) for 30 min in two groups.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- age 18-35 years
- singleton pregnancy with cephalic term presentation
- tendency to do vaginal delivery
- having no medical or mental diseases
- having no pregnancy complications
- Intact membranes
- BMI<26
Exclusion Criteria:
- using oxytocin before and during the monitoring of contractions
- performing cesarean section for any reason except arrested delivery or pelvic constriction
- the birth weight< 2500 or >4000
- using the analgesia such as epidural anesthesia morphine and pethidine during the study
